results.title: A Writer's legacy
results.brief_description: Heather’s father believed in his daughter as a writer even when she did not believe in herself. He left her letters and memorabilia but the real legacy her father left her was the love of writing.

results.title: A World reborn
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Renaissance”.
Presents an excellent overview of history and contribution of the Renaissance. Traces the 300 years of this age from the early ideas of pioneers such as Petrach and Jan Hus, who sparked new ways of thinking, to innovators like Brunelleschi and Maciavelli, to the artistic, scientific and political revolutions of the High Renaissance, to the years when Europe finally accepted a vision of the world that was changed forever.

results.title: A World of his own
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Fair Go”.
One of a 7 part series which examines the impact of mental and physical disability on individual Australians and their families. They demonstrate the practical implications of coping with a disability in daily life at home, in the work place, at school and in the community. Presented from the viewpoint of the disabled person. This program is about 10 year old Matthew Ellis who is severely mentally retarded. Editor, Rod Adamson; camera, Tony Wilson.

results.title: A World of Festivals
results.creator_credit: Joy Barrow, Barry Sloane and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description: A series which captures the appeal, colour and cultural tradition of European festivals and their locations. The rituals, forms of behaviour, dress, music, folklore and fun behind each event are explored, so that a fascinating and colourful picture of other societies’ culture and traditions is presented.

results.title: A World of difference
results.creator_credit: Anthony Gilkison, Rayant Pictures and Sarah Erulkar
results.brief_description: About the manufacture, care and uses of textile fibres. Looks at the four main fibres - animal (wool), vegetable (cotton), chemical (nylon), and raw vegetable material (rayon). Examines the most commonly used fibres - the natural animal and vegetable fibres and those made chemically like nylon and terylene. Shows how an understanding of their natures helps in following the simple but necessary rules for avoiding trouble when washing, especially with the newer synthetics. Script, Sarah Erulkar; editor, Nicholas Gurney; music, Edward Williams; animation director, Henry Stringer.

results.title: A World apart
results.creator_credit: Sarah Radclyffe, Palace Films, British Screen, Atlantic, Working Title Films and Chris Menges
results.brief_description: An excellently acted and moving drama based on the real-life story of anti-Apartheid activist, Ruth First, written by Ruth’s own daughter, Shawn Slovo. Jodhi May plays an unhappy 13 year old girl, Molly, growing up in South Africa. Her mother (Barbara Hershey) journalist, has little time for Molly’s adolescent needs because all her time and energy is devoted to her fight against the South African government, a fight which eventually leads to her imprisonment. An enthralling movie of discrimination seen through the eyes of a child.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Radclyffe, Palace Films, British Screen, Atlantic, Working Title Films and Chris Menges

results.title: A Working woman in Korea
results.creator_credit: Gian Manara, Cheol-Yong Kang, MBC Korea, Asian Broadcasting Union and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “A Day in the Life of a Woman”.
Young Hee-Kim has been working as a car saleswoman with great success for a year, but she worries about her family and whether she should be spending such long hours away from them. The program looks at the dilemma faced by working women all over the world and one woman’s attempt to come to terms with it. Introduced by Franca Arena.

results.title: A Working couple
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Oliver Howes and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Most Japanese live in the big cities, many of them are salaried company workers, living in housing estates and traveling long distances to work. For many people, life is a struggle. This focuses of Mr Yokohama, a professional office employee and his wife who runs a chemist. Their lives provide an insight as to what its like to live in Tokyo, with a population of twelve million.
